sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Review


Power Poses
Amy Cuddy, a social scientist and TED speaker, studies body language (or nonverbal communication). She is particularly interested in nonverbal expressions of power. This is what our bodies do when we are—or feel—powerful. Cuddy believes that by changing our body language, we can change how powerful we feel.
To prove this point, she ran an experiment. First, she invited a number of candidates to be interviewed for a job. Next, immediately before the interview, Cuddy asked half the candidates to practice high-power poses for two minutes. The other candidates were asked to practice low-power poses for two minutes. Then the interviews were filmed and later watched by a panel of interviewers who were not told what the experiment was about. The panel judged the candidates who had practiced the high-power poses very favorably. However, the interviewers did not want to hire anyone who had done the low-power posing.
Cuddy gives a simple, biological explanation for this. She says that striking some poses releases particular chemicals in the brain. For low-power poses, these chemicals make people believe they are powerless. Feeling powerless, they often do not cope well with stress, and they are less positive. Conversely, Cuddy found that high-power poses release other chemicals in the brain. These tell people that they are powerful, so they then feel confident. Interestingly, Cuddy found that it didn’t matter what qualifications a candidate had, or even what he or she actually said in the interview. “It’s not about the content of the speech,” explains Cuddy, “It’s about the presence that they’re bringing to the speech.”
Cuddy’s research suggests that doing a high-power pose for two minutes—even if we might look a bit silly when doing it—may make us feel more powerful. Feeling more powerful may very well make us believe we are more powerful. And that belief has the power to change our lives.

items.q: What is the passage mainly about?
options: what we can learn from body language
why people use nonverbal communication
how nonverbal expressions of power affect us

items.q: Which definition of candidate is being used in this passage?
options: someone campaigning in a political election
someone applying for a job
someone taking an exam

items.q: What was true of Cuddy’s experiment?
options: All the candidates practiced high-power poses.
The interviewers wanted to hire those who practiced high-power poses.
The panel of interviewers knew about the experiment before they saw the candidates.

items.q: What does this refer to in paragraph 3?
options: the panel of interviewers
low- and high-power poses
the results of the experiment

items.q: What can you conclude from paragraph 3?
options: Most people feel powerless when they have a job interview.
It is natural to feel more or less powerful depending on the pose you make.
When people give a speech, they feel more powerful.

items.q: Which words in paragraph 3 explain the meaning of content ?
options: what he or she actually said in the interview
the presence that they’re bringing to the speech
high-power poses release other chemicals in the brain

items.q: Look at the excerpt below from paragraph 3. “For low-power poses, these chemicals make people believe they are powerless.— A —Feeling powerless, they often do not cope well with stress, and they are less positive. Conversely, Cuddy found that high-power poses release other chemicals in the brain. These tell people that they are powerful, so they then feel confident.— B — Interestingly, Cuddy found that it didn’t matter what qualifications a candidate had, or even what he or she actually said in the interview.”— C — Where would the following sentence fit best? The more confident they feel, the better they perform certain tasks, such as job interviews.
options: A
B
C

items.q: What does Cuddy believe about power poses?
options: It’s sometimes useful to practice low-power poses.
People don’t look silly when they are practicing a high-power pose.
If you practice a high-power pose you may feel more powerful.

items.q: According to the last paragraph, what happens first?
options: You feel powerful.
You believe you are powerful.
You make a high-power pose for two minutes.

items.q: Which sentence from the passage gives the main idea?
options: Cuddy says that striking some poses releases particular chemicals in the brain.
Feeling more powerful may very well make us believe we are more powerful.
Cuddy believes that by changing our body language, we can change how powerful we feel.

sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Extension


Fear Is Spread by Body Language, Study Says
In the past, scientists have said that human emotions are communicated mainly by facial expressions. But a new study suggests that body posture may be as important as the face in communicating emotions such as fear.  The study shows that images of fear affect the emotional part of the brain. Since the link between the emotional brain and action is stronger than the link between the visual brain and action, viewing fearful body expressions may automatically prepare the observer to respond to fear.
For the study, neuroscientist Beatrice de Gelder and her colleagues used still images of 18 actors with their faces blocked out performing emotional actions like opening a door and finding an armed robber standing in front of them. The actors also had to perform neutral actions like pouring water into a glass or combing their hair.  These images were then shown to study participants inside a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) machine that measured the brain activity of the person watching the pictures.
The researchers found that viewing happy body postures increased activity only in brain regions that processed visual information. However, viewing fearful body postures activated brain regions that process emotional information, as well as those that govern motor processes.
The study shows that the brain's emotional response to fear is probably simpler and more automatic than some researchers have assumed in the past. At a fearful moment, animals and humans need to be response ready, since they are given only a fraction of a second to evaluate the situation.
Several teams around the world, including de Gelder's, are conducting experiments in which the brain activity of participants is scanned while they're watching movies. This enables scientists to study how emotional actions are based on movement.
In the future, such research may help scientists diagnose mental diseases such as Alzheimer's and disorders such as autism and schizophrenia. It may also be used in building robotic human companions, which could be improved by building principles of "emotional movement" into them.

items.q: What could be another title for this passage?
options: Beatrice de Gelder’s Greatest Discovery
The Fear and Posture Connection
How Movies Affect Us

items.q: According to paragraph 1, which link is the strongest?
options: the link between the visual brain and action
the link between the emotional brain and action
the link between the emotional and the visual brains

items.q: What did scientists believe about fear before de Gelder’s study?
options: Fear is mainly communicated through facial expressions.
Fear is caused by a simple process in the brain.
Fear is an automatic response.

items.q: According to paragraph 2, which of the following is an emotional activity ?
options: having a gun pointed at you
taking a drink of water
brushing your teeth

items.q: Which sentence from the passage best represents the main idea?
options: But a new study suggests that body posture may be as important as the face in communicating emotions such as fear.
The researchers found that viewing happy body postures increased activity only in brain regions that processed visual information.
In the future, such research may help scientists diagnose mental diseases such as Alzheimer's and disorders such as autism and schizophrenia.

items.q: In de Gelder’s study, what is the most probable reason for the actors’ faces being blocked out ?
options: because the actors were not attractive
so participants would focus on body posture only
to make participants imagine what the actors looked like

items.q: According to paragraph 3, viewing happy postures activated which part of the brain?
options: the visual part
the emotional part
the motor processes part

items.q: According to paragraph 5, how is de Gelder’s current research different to her previous research?
options: She’s focusing on movement.
She’s focusing on brain activity.
She’s focusing on emotional actions.

items.q: What does the last paragraph say about research in the future?
options: It may help Alzheimer’s patients express themselves.
It may aid scientists in developing companion robots.
It may get rid of autism and schizophrenia.

items.q: What is the following sentence an example of? The study shows that the brain's emotional response to fear is probably simpler and more automatic than some researchers have assumed in the past.
options: the results of the experiment
an explanation of how the experiment was done
the reason scientists decided to conduct the experiment

sections.passage:
Reading Skills

The Polygraph
In 1921, medical student and police officer, John Augustus Larson, invented the polygraph—or lie detector. He believed that people have certain physiological responses when they lie.  Their bodies react differently when they lie compared to when they are telling the truth. 
Larson tried out his invention on many people to compare normal responses (when a person is telling the truth) to abnormal responses (when a person is lying). The polygraph worked by measuring a person’s heart rate, blood pressure, breathing rate, and sweat production.  Sensors were attached to a person’s body, and the person was asked a series of questions. If their heart rate and blood pressure rose, they became sweaty and began breathing more rapidly, this indicated that the person may be lying. 
Larson’s tests were generally successful, and his invention was named one of the world’s greatest inventions. Scientists aren’t completely convinced of the test’s accuracy, however.  In some cases, a person may be telling the truth but feel stress from the test. Their heart rate, blood pressure, etc. may rise even though they are not lying. The scientific community maintains that the polygraph is a useful but imperfect tool.


a.
hypothesis
b.
method
c.
results
d.
conclusion

items.q: Larson’s tests were generally successful, and his invention was named one of the world’s greatest inventions.
Larson tried out his invention on many people to compare normal responses to abnormal responses.
The scientific community maintains that the polygraph is a useful, but imperfect tool.
He believed that people have certain physiological responses when they lie.

sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Read the excerpt from Amy Cuddy’s 2012 TED Talk and answer the questions.
sections.passage:
TED Talk Comprehension

Amy Cuddy—Your Body Language Shapes Who You Are

So at the end of my first year at Harvard, a student who had not talked in class the entire semester, who I had said, “Look, you’ve gotta participate or else you’re going to fail,” came into my office. I really didn’t know her at all. And she said, she came in totally defeated, and she said, “I’m not supposed to be here.” And that was the moment for me. Because two things happened. One was that I realized, oh my gosh, I don’t feel like that anymore. You know. I don’t feel that anymore, but she does, and I get that feeling. And the second was, she is supposed to be here! Like, she can fake it, she can become it. So I was like, “Yes, you are! You are supposed to be here! And tomorrow you’re going to fake it, you’re going to make yourself powerful, and, you know, you’re gonna—” “And you’re going to go into the classroom, and you are going to give the best comment ever.” You know? And she gave the best comment ever, and people turned around and they were like, oh my God, I didn’t even notice her sitting there, you know?
She comes back to me months later, and I realized that she had not just faked it till she made it, she had actually faked it till she became it. So she had changed. And so I want to say to you, don’t fake it till you make it. Fake it till you become it.

items.q: What was one of the things that happened when the student came into Amy Cuddy’s office? a. She realized she was feeling the same way as the student. b. She told the girl that she was supposed to be there.
What advice did Cuddy give her student? a. to speak in class even if she didn’t feel like it b. to do more work outside of class
How did the student change? a. She started noticing other classmates. b. She became more confident.
to understand something
to pretend, to act like something you are not
to feel like you have no chance of succeeding
